content.text:
Regular Expressions
A Regular Expression is a sequence of characters that forms a search pattern.
Regex is a common shorthand for a regular expression.
JavaScript RexExp is an Object for handling Regular Expressions.

RegExp are be used for:

Text searching
Text replacing
Text validation

codes.code:
let text = "Visit W3Schools";
let n = text.search(/w3schools/i);

content.text: w3schools  is a pattern (to be used in a search).
i  is a modifier (modifies the search to be case-insensitive).
Regular expressions are often used with the string methods:

data: Returns the index of the first match

codes.code:
let text = "Visit W3Schools";
let n = text.match(/W3schools/);

let text = "Visit Microsoft!";
let result = text.replace(/Microsoft/i, "W3Schools");

let text = "Visit W3Schools";
let n = text.search(/W3Schools/);

content.text: In a regular expression an alteration is denoted with a vertical line character |.
An alteration matches any of the alternatives separated with |.

codes.code:
let text = "Black, white, red, green, blue, yellow.";

let result = text.match(/red|green|blue/g);
/pattern/flags

content.text:
Regular expression flags are parameters that can modify how a pattern is used,
such as making it case-insensitive or global.
The /g flag matches all occurrences of the pattern, rather than just the first one.
The /i flag makes a match case-insensitive: /abc/i matches "abc", "AbC", "ABC".

codes.code:
// Match words
const pattern = /\w/;

content.text: Metacharacters are characters with a special meaning.
They can be used to match digts, words, spaces, and more.
A word character is a character a-z, A-Z, 0-9, including _ (underscore).

codes.code:
// Match at least one zero
const pattern = /0+/;

content.text: Quantifiers define the numbers of characters or expressions to match.

Code
  Description


  x*
  Matches zero or more occurrences of x


  x?
  Matches zero or one occurrences of x


  x{n}
  Matches n occurences of x
x? matches zero or one occurrences of x.

SyntaxNameDescription
^String boundaryMatches the beginning of a string
$String boundaryMatches the end of a string
\bWord boundaryMatches the beginning or end of a word
(?=...)LookaheadMatches the subsequent string
(?<=...)LookbehindMatches the previous string
The ^ metacharacter matches the beginning of a string.
The $ metacharacter matches the end of a string.

codes.code:
// Match Digits
const pattern = /[0-9]/;

content.text: Character Classes are characters enclosed in square brackets [].
A character class matches any character from a set within brackets.

Class
  Description


  [a]
  Matches the character between the brackets


  [abc]
  Matches all characters between the brackets
  

  [a-z]
  Matches all characters in the range from a to z


  [0-9]
  Matches all characters in the range from 0 to 9
